par.text: Cobalt is a silvery-white, brittle, heavy metal. It is malleable and ductile. Polished cobalt has a bluish tinge. It is a strong ferromagnetic, meaning it has the ability to become magnetised in a magnetic field. It has the highest Curie point (1121

C), which is the temperature at which a substance loses its ferromagnetic properties. Cobalt does not corrode in air. At elevated temperatures it reacts with sulphur, oxygen and the halogens.
